content.title: Who We Are
content.text:
ObjectTeller has been developed at the University of Michigan Medical School for one purpose,
to speed up the rate at which new health knowledge is routinely used to help people be well.
Here in the Department of Learning Health Sciences we are dedicated to the scientific pursuit of
infrastructures - comprised of people, processes, and technologies - for routine, sustainable learning
about how to continuously improve human health. ObjectTeller has been created within our
Division of Learning and Knowledge Systems to address the challenge of managing massive amounts
of rapidly changing computable health knowledge. It is for storing, curating, preserving, and protecting
health knowledge, and for making it accessible on demand for all people to use at any time.
ObjectTeller enables its users to be effective movers of health knoweldge into practice.

content.title: Open Source
content.text:
ObjectTeller is an open source software system for managing computable health knowledge. As such,
its code can be inspected and extended, and its uses can multiply. ObjectTeller has been designed to
promote open sharing of the computable health knowledge in its libraries too. And ObjectTeller maintains
detailed records and audit trails that its users are encouraged to open to the world of linked data.
At the University of Michigan Medical School, we understand that openness begets trust and that is why
with ObjectTeller, we are committed to supporting openness in all things.

content.title: What is ObjectTeller?
content.text: It&#39s an app for managing computable health knowledge.

content.title: Is ObjectTeller free?
content.text: Yes. Download it and put it to use!

content.title: Who built ObjectTeller?
content.text: A team of dedicated professionals at the University of Michigan.

content.title: Can I help further develop ObjectTeller?
content.text: Yes! Join our technical community by sending us an email to dlhs.knowledge.grid@umich.edu.
